BC-FAMILY-COLUMN-BOS 
HOW BUSINESS GETS WHAT IT WANTS 

   (For use by New York Times News Service clients)  
 By LINDA WELTNER  
 c.2000 The Boston Globe  
 

   My townsmen are up in arms. The letters to our local paper read:
``Liberties are being taken away.'' ``What freedom will they go
after next?'' ``I find it frightening . . . that this freedom can
be denied so easily.''

   The issue? The Marblehead Board of Health has banned smoking in
public places. This is the way a healthy democracy works. If enough
people object, they have redress through the voting booth. What
disturbs me far more, what in fact chills me to the bone, is that
powerful international corporations play by different rules. Their
conscious intent is to undermine the people's ability to act on
their own behalf.

   Representatives of the telecommunications industry recently
appeared before the Board of Selectmen, bringing Marblehead face to
face with what happens when corporations collide with grass-roots
democracy.

   According to B. Blake Levitt, author of ``Electromagnetic
Fields: A Consumer's Guide to the Issues and How to Protect
Ourselves,'' before 1996 protesters were able to cite numerous
studies as well as data collected from foreign military bases that
indicated various health effects from nonionizing microwave
radiation _ generated by cell phones _ among them increased
permeability of the blood-brain barrier; damage to the immune
system; numerous cancers; and DNA damage. Unlike the output of a
100-watt light bulb, 100 watts of ultrahigh frequencies in the
microwave band are maximally absorbed by human tissue, with the
result that long-term low-level exposure has been implicated in
increases in breast cancer, leukemia, cataracts, immune
suppression, and brain tumors. When citizens pointed out these
findings to town officials, they frequently responded by refusing
to accept cell phone towers.

   The Telecommunications Bill of 1996 removed this pesky obstacle
to expanding cell phone use by taking away a community's right to
refuse to site antennae. Discussion of health or environmental
effects has been prohibited at public hearings, since such
considerations are irrelevant to tower siting. Although this raises
issues of free speech, as well as public policy questions about
government's role in protecting the health of citizens, it takes
time and money to move these issues through the courts. Every year
that passes, more and more antennae go up.

   After 1996, some elected officials continued to resist the lure
of the lavish licensing fees cell phone companies were offering.
Some towns set up moratoriums while they pondered the issues.
Others developed siting ordinances that confined towers to areas
with large setbacks (1,500 feet is optimal) from residences,
schools, hospitals, and nursing homes. This put towns like
Marblehead, with its troublesome 500-feet setback requirement,
directly in the path of the grid of wireless communications planned
to extend seamlessly across the United States.

   How does a corporation get what it wants when the will of the
people opposes it? The National Rifle Association makes campaign
contributions to candidates willing to ignore the wishes of the
majority. W.R. Grace withheld information from consumers that would
warn them that its insulation contained asbestos. Monsanto uses its
clout with the FDA to make sure that genetically altered foods are
not labeled so that in the future it will be impossible to trace
any harm they may cause. The tobacco industry upped the amount of
an addictive substance in cigarettes.

   The telecommunications industry has taken another tack. It is
presently proposing that our state Legislature create a category it
calls a minor facility, which includes any antennae placed on or in
an existing structure, even within historic districts. Such
``minor'' facilities, no matter how high their power output, would
be subject to a statewide ``streamlined permitting process'' that
would override local bylaws.

   Goodbye, home rule. Farewell, local control.

   In her book, ``The Working Life,'' Joanne Ciulla laments that we
have sacrificed the freedom of the workplace for the freedom of the
marketplace, enslaving ourselves to our employers in order to
maximize our options as consumers. As corporations have grown large
enough to dominate and undermine the political life of a once free
people, they have promoted the convenience of their products while
using every means at their disposal to downplay any damage they may
do the user. (It is no coincidence that Congress has ended its
funding of independent research into the effects of microwave
radiation.) It seems to me that, as cell phone owners, Americans
are all too willing to sacrifice the freedom of the polling place
for the freedom of the marketplace.

   Are we still citizens, or merely consumers? Are we willing to
let corporations silence all protest? Have we actually reached the
point where the only vote that counts is a purchase?
